conclusion: A child with a mass of 30 kg is sitting on a sled with a mass of 10 kg. An adult pulls the sled with a force of 100 N at an angle of 37° above the horizontal. The sled moves at a constant speed along the horizontal ground.
The sled moves at constant speed, meaning acceleration = 0.
Gravity acts downward (mg), and the normal force (N) acts upward from the ground. There must be friction (f) opposing the motion.

premise: Since the sled moves at constant speed, the net force in the horizontal direction is zero: F·cos(37°) - f = 0
For vertical forces, we also have equilibrium: N - (m_child + m_sled)·g + F·sin(37°) = 0

conclusion: Pressure is defined as force per unit area: P = N/A
The problem doesn't provide the area of the sled contacting the ground. The question is likely asking for the normal force per unit area, which is just the normal force N.

premise: The magnitude of the normal force exerted by the ground on the sled (and equally by the sled on the ground) is 340 N.
conclusion: The magnitude of the pressure (normal force) exerted by the sled on the ground is 340 N.
